Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Content: The diagram represents how light travels inside one type of telescope.
problems/MA19HSP/media/1a.jpg
Which of the following determines how the secondary mirror is positioned in this telescope?

A.Choice: The energy of a light wave is proportional to its frequency.

B.Choice: The frequency of a light wave is inversely proportional to its wavelength.

C.Choice: When a light wave is refracted, the change in speed depends on its wavelength.

D.Choice: When a light wave is reflected, the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection are equal.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: Which of the following changes to the resistance and the voltage will always increase the current in a circuit?

A.Choice: a decrease in both the resistance and the voltage

B.Choice: an increase in both the resistance and the voltage

C.Choice: a decrease in the resistance and an increase in the voltage

D.Choice: an increase in the resistance and a decrease in the voltage

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy at the macroscopic scale can be accounted for as either motions of particles and objects or energy stored in fields.
Content: Which of the following statements describes how energy changes as water vapor cools from 120°C to 110°C?

A.Choice: The kinetic energy of the water molecules decreases as energy is released into the environment.

B.Choice: The potential energy of the water molecules increases as energy is released into the environment.

C.Choice: The kinetic energy of the water molecules increases as energy is absorbed from the environment.

D.Choice: The potential energy of the water molecules decreases as energy is absorbed from the environment.

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to show that the total momentum of a system of interacting objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.
Content: The table below shows the mass and the velocity of three vehicles.
problems/MA19HSP/media/4a.jpg
Which of the following lists the vehicles in order of their momentum, from greatest to least?

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: The illustration below represents a physics teacher doing a classroom demonstration. He pulls a pendulum made with a bowling ball toward his face until it touches his nose. Then he lets go of the ball.
problems/MA19HSP/media/5a.jpg
Which of the following BEST explains why the bowling ball does not touch the teacher again as it swings?

A.Choice: A small amount of energy is lost due to gravity.

B.Choice: Some kinetic energy is lost due to air resistance and friction.

C.Choice: The pendulum's inertia acts in opposition to its potential energy.

D.Choice: The pendulum's kinetic energy gradually turns to potential energy.

Content: Which of the following is the BEST example of conduction?

A.Choice: The glass roof of a greenhouse reflects energy.

B.Choice: Warm air rises above cool air in the atmosphere.

C.Choice: Sunlight transfers energy to a concrete sidewalk.

D.Choice: The handle of a pan on a hot stove becomes warm.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The graph represents how a motorcycle's position changes over time.
problems/MA19HSP/media/7a.jpg
Which of the following graphs BEST represents the motorcycle's velocity over time?

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: A 6 V battery is connected to a 24 V resistor to create a circuit. The 6 V battery is then replaced with a 12 V battery.
How does the current change in the circuit when the 12 V battery is used instead of the 6 V battery?

A.Choice: The current is reduced by one-fourth.

B.Choice: The current is reduced by one-half.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: A laser beam travels from a telescope on Earth to a reflector on the Moon and then back to the telescope in 2.56 seconds. Based on this information, how far is the Moon from Earth?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that an electric current can produce a magnetic field and that a changing magnetic field can produce an electric current.
Content: Which of the following actions can produce an electric current in a loop of wire?

A.Choice: spinning the wire near a battery

B.Choice: placing a resistor at the end of the wire

C.Choice: heating a switch and placing it on the wire

D.Choice: moving a magnet up and down near the wire

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy at the macroscopic scale can be accounted for as either motions of particles and objects or energy stored in fields.
Content: A cyclist and bicycle have a combined mass of 90 kg. Starting from rest, the cyclist rides down a 10 m high hill and up a 7 m high hill without pedaling the bicycle.
What is the potential energy of the cyclist and bicycle at the top of the 7 m hill with respect to the bottom of the 7 m hill?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS TWO PARTS.
The diagram below represents one type of wave created on a guitar string when the string is plucked. The string has a length of 0.65 m and vibrates at a frequency of 880 Hz.
problems/MA19HSP/media/12a.jpg
Calculate the velocity of this wave on the string. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
The wave on the guitar string also creates sound waves in the air. The speed of the sound waves is 340 m/s in air. The pitch created by the guitar string matches the pitch heard by an observer.
Compare the frequency AND wavelength of the wave on the guitar string to the frequency and wavelength of the sound waves in the air.

SubTopics: Develop and use a model to illustrate that energy at the macroscopic scale can be accounted for as either motions of particles and objects or energy stored in fields.
Content: Liquid water in a sealed container is placed near a window. Over a few hours, the water in the container changes into water vapor.
Which diagram models the change in energy and particle movement of the water?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Some insects can detect frequencies of light that are lower than the frequencies the human eye can detect. Based on this information, which of the following types of radiation do these insects detect?

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The graph shows how the velocity of a car changes over time.
problems/MA19HSP/media/15a.jpg
What is the acceleration of the car?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Which of the following statements describes the motion of air particles as a sound wave moves across a room?

A.Choice: The air particles move in circles inside the sound wave.

B.Choice: The air particles move across the room with the sound wave.

C.Choice: The air particles move back and forth, parallel to the direction of the sound wave.

D.Choice: The air particles move back and forth, perpendicular to the direction of the sound wave.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: A student arranges light bulbs, wires, and a battery to create some circuits. All of the light bulbs have the same resistance, and each battery has the same voltage. One of the light bulbs in each circuit is labeled X.
In which circuit would the light bulb labeled X be brightest?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: Some students have two metal spheres, each with the same mass. The students hang each sphere by a string from a ruler. They give one sphere a positive charge and the other sphere a negative charge. The spheres do not appear to move when they are charged. The diagram shows the setup.
problems/MA19HSP/media/18a.jpg
Which of the following changes could the students make to INCREASE the force of attraction between the spheres?

A.Choice: use metal spheres that have less mass

B.Choice: give both metal spheres a positive charge

C.Choice: decrease the distance between the metal spheres

D.Choice: remove the positive charge from the sphere on the left

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Which of the following is a characteristic of a mechanical wave but NOT a characteristic of an electromagnetic wave?

A.Choice: The wave needs a medium to transmit energy.

B.Choice: The wave maintains a constant speed within a medium.

C.Choice: When the amplitude of the wave increases, the speed of the wave increases.

D.Choice: When the frequency of the wave increases, the wavelength of the wave decreases.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: A load with a resistance of 5 V is connected to a 30 V source. How much current is drawn by the load?

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: Neglecting friction, which of the following statements describes the relationship between the energy of an object and the work done on it?

A.Choice: Work is needed for an object to keep a constant kinetic energy.

B.Choice: Work is needed for an object to keep a constant potential energy.

C.Choice: Increasing the kinetic energy of an object increases the amount of work needed to stop it.

D.Choice: Increasing the potential energy of an object decreases the amount of work needed to stop it.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: A box is moving at a constant velocity along a rough, horizontal surface. An applied force opposes the frictional force, as represented in the free-body force diagram below.
problems/MA19HSP/media/22a.jpg
Which free-body force diagram represents the forces acting on the object the moment after the applied force is removed, but while the box is still moving forward?

SubTopics: Analyze data to support the claim that Newton's second law of motion is a mathematical model describing change in motion (the acceleration) of objects when acted on by a net force.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS FOUR PARTS.

A moving walkway is like a sidewalk that moves at a constant speed. It is used to transport people from one location to another within a large building, such as an airport. The diagram shows a moving walkway.
problems/MA19HSP/media/23a.jpg

The table shows data about two people on the same moving walkway. Person 1 steps onto the walkway from rest and stands on it. Person 2 steps onto the walkway while already walking and continues to walk.
problems/MA19HSP/media/23b.jpg
Using the data for person 1, calculate the speed of the walkway. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Stepping onto the walkway, person 1 accelerates from an initial speed of 0 m/s to the speed of the walkway in 0.6 s.
Calculate the acceleration of person 1. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Calculate the net force that accelerated person 1. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Person 1 and person 2 have the same acceleration as they step onto the moving walkway.
Identify whether the net force acting on person 1 is greater than, less than, or equal to the net force acting on person 2. Explain your answer.
A student investigating heat transfer places a 60°C piece of heated aluminum into a beaker of 20°C water. Which of the following best describes the process of heat transfer in the investigation?

A.Choice: The aluminum transfers heat to the water mostly by conduction, and within the water, heat is transferred mostly by radiation.

B.Choice: The aluminum transfers heat to the water mostly by conduction, and within the water, heat is transferred mostly by convection.

C.Choice: The aluminum transfers heat to the water mostly by radiation, and within the water, heat is transferred mostly by conduction.

D.Choice: The aluminum transfers heat to the water mostly by radiation, and within the water, heat is transferred mostly by convection.

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to show that the total momentum of a system of interacting objects is conserved when there is no net force on the system.
Content: The diagram shows a compressed spring between two carts that are initially at rest. Cart X has a mass of 4 kg and cart Y has a mass of 2 kg. A thread tied to a hook on each cart holds the carts together.
problems/MA19HSP/media/25a.jpg
When the thread is cut, the spring is released and the carts move apart. How does the speed of cart Y compare to the speed of cart X after the thread is cut?

A.Choice: The speed of cart Y is half the speed of cart X.

B.Choice: The speed of cart Y is the same as the speed of cart X.

C.Choice: The speed of cart Y is two times the speed of cart X.

D.Choice: The speed of cart Y is four times the speed of cart X.

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Communicate technical information about how some technological devices use the principles of wave behavior and wave interactions with matter to transmit and capture information and energy.
Content: Which property of waves explains why a straight flower stem may look bent when placed in a glass of water?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Which of the following types of waves is longitudinal?

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: A 6 kg table has a net force of 15 N acting on it. What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the table?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that an electric current can produce a magnetic field and that a changing magnetic field can produce an electric current.
Content: A student began an investigation by wrapping several coils of insulated wire around a steel nail. As shown in the diagram, when the ends of the wire were connected to a battery, the student was able to pick up several steel paper clips with the end of the steel nail.
problems/MA19HSP/media/29a.jpg
problems/MA19HSP/media/29b.jpg
Which of the following claims is best supported by the student's investigation?

A.Choice: An electric current in the wire produces a magnetic field.

B.Choice: An electric current in the wire produces a potential difference.

C.Choice: A magnetic field can produce an electric current in the wire.

D.Choice: A magnetic field can produce an electric current in steel paper clips.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: A space shuttle enters Earth's upper atmosphere with a velocity of 11,200 m/s and experiences an acceleration of –70 m/s².
What is the magnitude of the shuttle's velocity 10 s after the shuttle enters the upper atmosphere?

SubTopics: Design and evaluate a device that works within given constraints to convert one form of energy into another form of energy.
Content: A ball is launched horizontally when a spring is released, as shown below.
problems/MA19HSP/media/31a.jpg
A student knows the amount of stored elastic potential energy in the spring before it is released. What additional quantity can the student determine using only this piece of information?

C.Choice: the velocity of the ball just before it hits the ground

D.Choice: the kinetic energy of the ball just as the spring is fully released

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.

Inflatable launchers are large, air-filled bags that float on the surface of the water at lakes, water parks, and community pools. A launcher works by transferring energy from one person to another. A person sitting on a launcher is launched into the air when another person jumps onto the bag. The diagram shows a boy and a girl using an inflatable launcher at a lake.
problems/MA19HSP/media/32a.jpg
The 75 kg girl is standing on a platform 15 m above the top of the launcher.
Calculate the gravitational potential energy of the girl relative to the top of the launcher. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
The girl steps off the platform and lands on the launcher.
Describe how the girl's kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy change during the time interval that begins when she steps off the platform and ends just before she lands on the launcher.
The boy is launched several meters into the air but wants to be launched higher.
Describe one change that could be made so that the boy would be launched higher. Explain your reasoning.

SubTopics: Use algebraic expressions and the principle of energy conservation to calculate the change in energy of one component of a system when the change in energy of the other component(s) of the system, as well as the total energy of the system including any energy entering or leaving the system, is known. Identify any transformations from one form of energy to another, including thermal, kinetic, gravitational, magnetic, or electrical energy, in the system.
Content: Four students took turns pushing a box. The table below shows the forces they exerted on the box, the distances they pushed it, and the amount of time they pushed it.
problems/MA19HSP/media/33a.jpg
Which two students did the same amount of work?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: The frequency of a note played on a piano is 262 Hz. Given that the velocity of sound at 20°C is 343 m/s, what is the wavelength of the note?

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: The diagram below represents the gravitational attraction forces between two masses.
problems/MA19HSP/media/35a.jpg
Which of the following combinations will result in the GREATEST force of gravitational attraction between two masses?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: The table shows the speed of sound in various substances under different conditions.
problems/MA19HSP/media/36a.jpg
Which of the following conclusions is BEST supported by the data in the table?

A.Choice: Sound generally travels at a faster speed in solid substances than in liquid substances.

B.Choice: Sound generally travels at a faster speed in gaseous substances than in liquid substances.

C.Choice: Sound generally travels at a slower speed when the temperature of a substance is increased.

D.Choice: Sound generally travels at a slower speed when the temperature of a substance is decreased.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The diagram below represents two forces acting on a wagon being pulled to the left. The force applied to the wagon is labeled Fₐ and the force of friction on the wagon is labeled F_f.
problems/MA19HSP/media/37a.jpg
If the net force acting on the wagon is 20 N to the left, what is the magnitude of the applied force?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: When 100 g of 20°C water is mixed with 50 g of 50°C water in a closed system, what is the final water temperature?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: A large rock from space hit the surface of the Moon. Why were humans able to see the bright flash that occurred but unable to hear the sound of the impact?

A.Choice: The sound waves required a medium for travel, but the light waves did not.

B.Choice: The low-energy sound waves were scattered by dust particles, but the high-energy light waves were not.

C.Choice: The high-energy sound waves were absorbed by the Moon's surface, and they were converted into visible light waves.

D.Choice: The sound waves arrived at Earth much later than the light waves, so they were not perceived as coming from the Moon.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: The graph shows the velocity of an object over time.
problems/MA19HSP/media/40a.jpg
Which of the following claims is supported by the graph?

A.Choice: The mass of the object is increasing.

B.Choice: The object has a displacement of zero.

C.Choice: The object has a constant acceleration.

D.Choice: The net force acting on the object is decreasing.

SubTopics: Use free-body force diagrams, algebraic expressions, and Newton's laws of motion to predict changes to velocity and acceleration for an object moving in one dimension in various situations.
Content: A person slides 1.2 m across a floor before coming to a stop. Why does the person come to a stop?

A.Choice: The force of gravity acts on the person.

B.Choice: The force of friction acts on the person.

C.Choice: The force of inertia fails to keep the person in motion.

D.Choice: The normal force is greater than the friction force that acts on the person.

SubTopics: Use mathematical representations of Newton's law of gravitation and Coulomb's law to both qualitatively and quantitatively describe and predict the effects of gravitational and electrostatic forces between objects.
Content: A student made the graph below to show how the amount of electrical force between two charged particles depends on another variable. The student's graph is missing a label for the x-axis.
problems/MA19HSP/media/42a.jpg
What should the student label the x-axis?

Topics: Waves & Their Applications In Technologies For Information Transfer
SubTopics: Use mathematical representations to support a claim regarding relationships among the frequency, wavelength, and speed of waves traveling within various media. Recognize that electromagnetic waves can travel through empty space (without a medium) as compared to mechanical waves that require a medium.
Content: Three wave properties are listed below.

:ibox:• Property 1: transverse

• Property 2: travel at the speed of light through a vacuum

• Property 3: travel faster through solids than through gases
Electromagnetic waves have which of these properties?

SubTopics: Provide evidence that when two objects of different temperature are in thermal contact within a closed system, the transfer of thermal energy from higher-temperature objects to lower-temperature objects results in thermal equilibrium, or a more uniform energy distribution among the objects and that temperature changes necessary to achieve thermal equilibrium depend on the specific heat values of the two substances.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS FOUR PARTS.

A student heated 235 g of water in a beaker until the water reached 100°C. The student removed the beaker from the heat and placed the beaker on a counter in a 23°C room. The student recorded the temperature of the water every 4 minutes for 20 minutes. The data are shown in the table.
problems/MA19HSP/media/44a.jpg
Did heat flow from the air to the water or from the water to the air? Include data from the table to support your answer.

A.Choice: from the air to the water

B.Choice: from the water to the air

Content: Identify the average temperature of the air in the room at 20 min.
Were the water and the air in thermal equilibrium at 20 min? Explain your answer.
The specific heat of water is 4.19 J/g • °C.
Calculate the change in thermal energy (to the nearest whole) of the water from 0 min to 20 min. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.

SubTopics: Evaluate simple series and parallel circuits to predict changes to voltage, current, or resistance when simple changes are made to a circuit.
Content: :ibox:THIS QUESTION HAS THREE PARTS.
Two circuits, W and X, are shown in the diagrams.
problems/MA19HSP/media/45a.jpg
problems/MA19HSP/media/45b.jpg
Circuit X has the same total resistance as circuit W, but circuit X has only one resistor, R₄.
Calculate the resistance of R₄. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Calculate the current through R₄. Show your calculations and include units in your answer.
Another circuit, Y, has the same battery and resistor as circuit X but also has another resistor, R₅, as shown.
problems/MA19HSP/media/45c.jpg
Determine whether adding R₅ increases or decreases the total current in circuit Y. Explain your reasoning.
